Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Smart-Grid Powered Green Communications in Heterogeneous Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Both the current wireless communication networks and the electricity grid infrastructure are on the verge of a major paradigm shift. The traditional cellular architecture is evolving into heterogeneous networks (HetNets) consisting of densely deployed macro/micro/pico-cell base stations (BSs). In such HetNets, coordinated transmissions are advocated to perform energy-efficient green communications. At the same time, the current power network infrastructure is also migrating toward a so-termed smart grid that promises unprecedented levels of monitorability and controllability. It is expected that all future communication systems will be powered by a smart grid. Integration of smart-grid technologies into system designs then holds the key to fully exploiting the potential of green communications in next-generation HetNets. This highlights the clear need for fundamental understanding and systematic exploration of smart-grid powered green communications in HetNet deployments.

To this end, the present project is centered on transformative analytical and algorithmic tools for smart-grid powered green communications. The vision is to establish a comprehensive framework based on state-of-the-art optimization approaches to jointly design green HetNets along with critically relevant smart grid operations. By cross-fertilizing ideas between these two fields, the ultimate goal is to set forth a unified treatment for modeling, analyzing, and designing resource management schemes for smart-grid powered HetNets. The engineering outcome of the proposed research is a suite of protocols for distributed, real-time implementation of basestation activation, coordinated beamforming in HetNets, as well as renewable energy harvesting and storage, demand response, and unit commitment operations for smart grids. Creating energy-efficient, distributed, real-time algorithms will greatly enhance the performance of emerging wireless cellular networks while reducing carbon emissions and enhancing the green communication solution to climate change and global warming. This project also addresses the broader impacts of improving undergraduate STEM education, increasing participation of under-represented minorities, and promoting a scientifically literate public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From a high-level vantage point, this project is at the cross-roads of the wireless communication networks and the electricity grid infrastructure, that are both on the verge of major paradigm shifts. The traditional cellular architecture is evolving into heterogeneous networks (HetNets), where coordinated transmissions can effect energy-efficient and “green” communications. On the other hand, our power network infrastructure is also migrating toward a so-termed “smart grid” that is envisioned to have unprecedented levels of monitorability and controllability, and also supply renewable energy sources to power future communication systems. Integration of smart-grid technologies into system designs then holds the key to green communications in next-generation HetNets. This project has contributed analytical and algorithmic foundations for smart-grid powered green communications to realize the vision of a comprehensive framework based on state-of-the-art optimization tools to jointly design green HetNets along with critically relevant smart grid operations. By cross-fertilizing ideas between these two fields, it has made transformative steps toward a unified treatment for modeling, analyzing, and designing resource management schemes for smart-grid powered HetNets. To this end, the major research outcomes of the project include: Robust smart-grid powered cooperative multipoint systems; Dynamic energy management for smart-grid-powered coordinated multipoint systems; Cooling-aware energy and workload management in data centers; Dynamic resource allocation for smart-grid powered MIMO downlink transmissions; Two-scale stochastic control for multipoint communication systems with renewables;  Distributed stochastic geographical load balancing with incentives; Optimal and scalable caching for 5G; Two-timescale stochastic dispatch of smart distribution grids; Real-time energy management in microgrids with reduced battery capacity requirements; Learn-and-adapt stochastic dual gradients for network resource allocation; Real-time power system state estimation (PSSE) and forecasting via deep neural networks; Data-driven priors for robust PSSE via Gauss-Newton unrolled neural networks; and Deep reinforcement learning for voltage regulation.  

Along with these research outcomes, this project had major outcomes also on the educational front. Ten PhDs were supported and the graduates are now faculty members (UC Santa Cruz, VaTech, RPI, Marquette, UC Irvine, Beijing Inst. of Technology), and researchers in the data science Industry (NextEra, Samsung, Google and Amazon).  Monthly reading group meetings were organized on advances related to network science, online convex optimization and machine learning for big data analytics with applications to sensing and resource allocation for communication, social, brain, and power networks with renewables and electric vehicles. Knowledge was disseminated through dozens of tutorials, keynote, plenary and colloquia presentations, journal and conference papers in flagship venues and international conferences, patents, half a dozen book chapters, and a research monograph. The research was recognized through four best paper awards (1 journal and 3 conferences), and the PI received additional prestigious awards over the course of the project. Those include the McKnight Presidential Endowed Chair at the University of Minnesota (since 2016); the IEEE Technical Field Fourier Award (2015); the IEEE-SPS "Norbert Wiener" Society Award (2019); EURASIP's "A. Papoulis" Society Award (2020); the IEEE ComSocEducation Award (2019); foreign membership of the AcademiaEuropaea (2020), and fellowships of the US National Academy of Inventors (2019); and the European Academy of Sciences (2020).
